title: Lefebvre
text:
Lefebvre () is a common northern French surname. Other variations include Lefèbvre, <a href="Lef%C3%A8vre">Lefèvre</a>, Lefeuvre (western France) and <a href="Lef%C3%A9bure">Lefébure</a> (northern France and Normandy).
In the <a href="Occitan">Occitan</a> and <a href="Arpitan">Arpitan</a> extension area, the variation is Fabre, Favre, Faure, Favret, Favrette or Dufaure and in <a href="Corsica">Corsica</a> Fabri (cf. Italian "<a href="Fabbri%20%28disambiguation%29">Fabbri</a>", "<a href="Fabri">Fabri</a>"). In Celtic-speaking <a href="Brittany">Brittany</a>, the corresponding name is Le Goff(ic), with the article "le" to translate <a href="Breton%20language">Breton</a> "ar".
For <a href="English%20language">Anglophone</a> pronunciation purposes, the name has evolved, especially in the United States and Anglophone regions of Canada mainly by <a href="Acadian">Acadian</a>s, among whom it is also a common surname, to LaFave, LeFave, Lefever and Lafevre, as well as other variant spellings. The English surname Feaver is also derived from Lefebvre. (See "<a href="Lef%C3%A8vre">Lefèvre</a>" for more.)
The name derives from "faber", the Latin word for "craftsman", "worker"; used in Late Latin in Gaul to mean <a href="metalsmith">smith</a>. Many northern French surnames (especially in <a href="Normandy">Normandy</a>) are used with the definite masculine article as a prefix (Lefebvre, Lefèvre; a more archaic spelling is Le Febvre), with the <a href="French%20articles%20and%20determiners">contracted masculine article</a> as a prefix (Dufaure) in the south of France, or without article/prefix (Favre, Faure) in the south of France, but the meaning is the same.
